awd_titl_txt: Long Term Development of Economic Landscapes in an Island Context
awd_abstract_narration:
Agricultural development is a cumulative process that occurs within dynamic social and ecological contexts. Because agricultural practices modify the environment, the collective impact of development changes the contexts of production for the next generation of farmers. In the tropics, food-production strategies have transformed the environment to create a mosaic of economically important species and microenvironments, which have allowed populations to extend production and innovate new techniques. Such environmental changes reside within wider social relationships, often those that negotiate power. Social relations impact the course of agricultural development by influencing the nature of labor mobilization and the use of landscapes. Scholars have long made a compelling case that change in Polynesian economies was motivated by elite demands for surplus, often taking advantage of favorable but circumscribed ecological conditions, but the evidence to model such processes are lacking in small scale political entities. Archaeological investigations of agricultural development provide information on cultivation strategies used in different places and times, relevant for understanding the role of social and environmental factors. These data have considerable temporal depth to support an examination of the complex interplay of social, economic, and physiological processes over time. 

Within this broader context, Dr. Seth Quintus and his co-investigators will undertake research to study the development of economic landscapes on Ta'u Island American Samoa. This research will be conducted by collecting data from a field and settlement system recently discovered in the interior uplands of the island. Traditional archaeological excavation and remote sensing methods will allow the team to understand the distribution of human activities, which will aid in identifying social differences within the population. The results of archaeological survey will be compared with an assessment of local variation in soil fertility and landscape evolution that might have affected the decisions of producers. Taxonomic analysis of wood charcoal assemblages will be used to investigate the role of tree-cropping in the production system, an important but not well understood component of Pacific production systems. These methods will provide an integrated examination of the coupled social and environmental processes that have created small island landscapes such as the one found on Ta'u. Socio-ecological dynamics helped to create the environments that we see today, which continue to be the focus of production for island residents. Understanding how these environments were created on isolated islands, which are considered ideal model systems, is fundamental to developing production strategies that can address concerns regarding food security and the promotion of food sovereignty today.

por.por_cntn:
Islands have long been conceptualized as microcosms or model systems for the investigation of human-environment relationships. This conceptualization stems from the bounded nature of these islands and their small size. Societies that developed in this island environments were, by necessity, largely self-sufficient. Archaeological research provides an opportunity to evaluate how communities in the past transformed their environments in such a way as to promote sustainable self-sufficiency. 

It was within this context that we explored the development of economic landscapes in the Manu'a group of American Samoa. While it has along been known that societies fundamentally altered their environments in the group, little research in West Polynesia has tracked the development of human-environment relations through time, especially in the interiors of islands. Our research highlighted a 1,500 year old sequence of environmental change on Ta'u island that resulted in a largely anthropogenic landscape. 

Communities began using interior resources on the island by the beginning of the 1st millennium AD, though the land use at this time appears to have been non-intensive and did not include the use of infrastructure. Economic trees, notably breadfruit, appear in the archaeological sequence in the middle of the 1st millennium AD, adding to the economic potential of the landscape. Human infrastructure, in the form of habitation terracing, was built at this same time but the tempo of construction increased drastically through time. Finally, long and mounded walls were constructed by the 17th century AD and later as population density required formal land boundaries.

The patterning of this construction activity provides insights into how communities engaged with their environments over time and as the landscape became more anthropogenic. Early construction of habitation terraces occurred where soil fertility was high and slope was low. These early communities were dispersed within this environmental zone. Over time, habitation terraces began to be built in areas of lower soil fertility and higher slope; these areas were more marginal and likely only settled because more optimal zones were not available because of earlier settlement. It is also apparent that social differences developed as the community grew. The largest habitation terraces, likely associated with local leaders was built in the most optimal zones characterized by high soil fertility and low slope. Access to fertile land provided local leaders an opportunity to accumulate, and redistribute resources, which is a central role of leaders in Polynesian chiefdoms. These areas were also centrally located, which is an important symbol of authority in Samoa and the rest of West Polynesia. In essence, the emergent characteristics of human-environmental relationships aided to create and maintain key social relationships. 

The island was not fully self sufficient, however. Most notably, stone out of which tools could be created was imported from the island of Tutuila, roughly 100-150 km away. While local stone was used for expedient activities, formal adzes were largely made of nonlocal stone from Tutuila. While such nonlocal stone was monopolized by leaders in other Polynesian societies, this was not the case on Ta'u where nonlocal stone was widely distributed. We hypothesize that this was an important concession of leaders that increased group integration and sustained the authority of leaders, while at the same time highlighting limits on their economic power.

Our research has several relevant contemporary ramifications. First, we demonstrate that the current environmental, both the biotic and abiotic components, are the outcome of a long sequence of human manipulation. This has implications for understanding the structure of vegetation, the movement of water across the slopes, and the potential risks of erosion. Without considering how humans have contributed to the environment, our understanding of the future structure and function of these ecosystems would be limited or incorrect. Second, the importance of social networks in the past illustrated by the importation of stone is an important lesson for community sustainability today. Importation tends to be associated with unsustainable practices today. However, importation can be part of a useful part of a resilient adaptive strategy in these island environments. Social networks, materialized through the exchange of goods, have long been a key adaptive strategy used by people in Oceania. It is likely that this behavioral strategy will continue to be an important one to use into the future. Finally, our results highlight the interplay between communities and their environment in developing both ecological and social relationships. As many others have noted, the separation between a natural and cultural environment is not that useful. Our results highlight the important recursive dynamics that result in environmental and social coevolution.
